name: DeSorrento, James
title: Founder / Chairman
notes: Former Marine Corps captain and UC Berkeley graduate who founded Triax Telecommunications in June 1982, building it to serve 342,000 cable subscribers before Mediacom acquired it for ~$740 million in 1999. Also founded the DeSo Foundation, a family nonprofit established after his son was killed in a car accident.

name: Coleman, William R.
employer: O'Melveny & Myers LLP (former); NAACP Legal Defense Fund (former)
title: Senior Partner (former); Secretary of Transportation (1975-1977)
notes: William T. Coleman Jr. (1920-2017) was the second African American to serve in a presidential Cabinet, appointed Secretary of Transportation by President Ford (1975-1977). Graduated summa cum laude from University of Pennsylvania (1941) and magna cum laude from Harvard Law School (1946). Worked with Thurgood Marshall on Brown v. Board of Education (1954). Served as President then Chairman of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund (1971-1997). Awarded Presidential Medal of Freedom by President Clinton in 1995.
ngos: NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund (Chairman, 1977-1997); Gerald R. Ford Foundation (Trustee)

name: Crow, Harlan

Subject of significant controversy since 2023 for undisclosed gifts and luxury trips to Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas.

name: Desmarais, Charles
title: Art Critic (Chief)
notes: Born April 21, 1949 in The Bronx, NY. Veteran museum director and art critic who served as President of the San Francisco Art Institute (2011-2015) before becoming the SF Chronicle's full-time art critic in 2016. Prior roles include Deputy Director for Art at the Brooklyn Museum (2005-2011), Director of the Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati (1995-2004), and Director of the Laguna Art Museum (1988-1994). Received the 2017 Rabkin Prize for Visual Arts Journalism.
ngos: San Francisco Art Institute (former President); Brooklyn Museum (former Deputy Director)

name: Gazzaniga, Michael S.

Pioneer of cognitive neuroscience, often called the 'father of cognitive neuroscience,' renowned for split-brain research conducted with Roger Sperry at Caltech (PhD 1964). Founded and directed the SAGE Center for the Study of the Mind at UCSB (2006-2023). Elected to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences (1997), the National Academy of Medicine (2005), and the National Academy of Sciences (2011).
